fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let (S \triangleright P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleright Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) be monad containers. A distributive law of S \triangleright P over T \triangleright Q is given by the data: \begin {align*} &u_1 : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to T) \to T \\ &u_2 : \prod _{s : S} \prod _{f : P\ s \to T} Q\ (u_1\ s\ f) \to S \\ &v_1 : \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to T\}} \prod _{q : Q\ (u_1\ s\ f)} P\ (u_2\ s\ f\ q) \to P\ s \\ &v_2 : \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to T\}} \prod _{q : Q\ (u_1\ s\ f)} \prod _{p : P\ (u_2\ s\ f\ q)} Q\ (f\ (v_1\ q\ p)) \\ \end {align*} where the following equalities hold: \begin {align*} u\ \iota ^S\ (\lambda \_ . t) &= (t , \lambda \_ . \iota ^S)\\ u\ s\ (\lambda \_. \iota ^T) &= (\iota ^T , \lambda \_. s)\\ v\ \{\iota ^S\}\ \{\lambda \_. t\} &= \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle \\ v\ \{s\}\ \{\lambda \_. \iota ^T\} &= \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle \\ \\ u_1\ (\sigma ^S\ s\ f)\ (g \circ \text {pr}^S) &= u_1\ s\ (u_1 \circ \langle f , g \rangle )\\ u_2\ (\sigma ^S\ s\ f)\ (g \circ \text {pr}^S) &= \sigma ^S \circ \langle u_2\ s\ (u_1 \circ \langle f , g \rangle ) , (u_2 \circ \langle f , g \rangle ) \circ v \rangle \\ \text {pr}^S_1\ (v_1\ q\ p) &= v_1\ q\ (\text {pr}^S_1\ p)\\ \text {pr}^S_2\ (v_1\ q\ p) &= v_1\ (v_2\ q\ (\text {pr}^S_1\ p)) \ (\text {pr}^S_2\ p)\\ v_2\ q\ p &= v_2\ (v_2\ q\ (\text {pr}^S_1\ p))\ (\text {pr}^S_2\ p)\\ \\ u_1\ s\ (\sigma ^T \circ \langle f , g \rangle ) &= \sigma ^T\ (u_1\ s\ f, u_1 \circ \langle u_2\ s\ f , g \circ v \rangle )\\ u_2\ s\ (\sigma ^T \circ \langle f , g \rangle ) &= (u_2 \circ \langle u_2\ s\ f , g \circ v \rangle ) \circ \text {pr}^T\\ v_1\ (\text {pr}^T_1\ q)\ (v_1\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\ p) &= v_1\ q\ p\\ v_2\ (\text {pr}^T_1\ q)\ (v_1\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\ p) &= \text {pr}^T_1\ (v_2\ q\ p)\\ v_2\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\ p &= \text {pr}^T_2\ (v_2\ q\ p) \end {align*} We use the notation \langle f , g \rangle := \lambda x . (f\ x , g\ x), and liberal use of currying and uncurrying.
u is defined as \langle u_1 , u_2 \rangle and v is defined as \langle v_1 , v_2 \rangle .

Any monad container S \triangleright P distributes over a representable monad container 1 \triangleright \lambda \_ . A in exactly one way.
307#247unstable-247.xmlProof2024125Chris Purdy By considering the data for a monad container distributive law, we get by the first four equalities, and for all s : S the isomorphism P\ s \to 1 \cong 1, that: \begin {align*} u\ s\ \_ &:= (* , \lambda \_ . s)\\ v\ p\ a &:= (a , p) \end {align*} u and v are entirely specified by the "unit" equalities, and the rest of the equalities hold. Hence this is the unique monad distributive law of S \triangleright P over 1 \triangleright \lambda \_ . A.

fr:title.text: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monad T is idempotent when T \eta = \eta T, which for monad containers immediately gives us \iota = s for all s : S, and hence S is contractible.

Another equivalent condition for a monad T to be idempotent is that \text {Id} is a distributive law TT \Rightarrow TT. For monad container distributive laws this implies futher that all positions are equal, so the set P\ \iota is subsingleton.

Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as Set functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.

Let S \triangleright P be a container. A monad container (or mnd-container) [uustalu2017] on S \triangleright P is given by the following data: \begin {align*} \iota &: S\\ \sigma &: \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to S) \to S\\ \text {pr} &: \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to S\}} P\ (\sigma \ s\ f) \to \sum _{p : P\ s} P\ (f\ p) \end {align*} For which the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a ) &= a\\ \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) &= a\\ \sigma \ (\sigma \ a\ f)\ (\lambda p . g\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\ (\text {pr}_2\ p)) &= \sigma \ a\ (\lambda p . \sigma \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_1\ p) &= \text {pr}_1\ p\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) \end {align*} We abbreviate \pi _1 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_1 and \pi _2 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_2. The last three laws hold up to the "associativity" law for \sigma .
